conclusion: Object A has mass m = 2 kg, Spring B has spring constant k₁ = 200 N/m, Spring C has unknown spring constant k₂, The distance ab = 60 cm = 0.6 m, Initially, object A is at rest with spring C undeformed, When spring C is pulled to position b, the tension in spring B equals the gravitational force on A.

premise: Initially, object A is at rest. Spring B must be stretched to support the weight of A.
When spring C is pulled to position b, the new tension in spring B is T_B = k₁x₁. We're told that this equals the gravitational force: k₁x₁ = mg
conclusion: x₁ = x₀, so the stretch of spring B doesn't change

premise: Since the stretch of spring B remains constant, the pulley system must maintain equilibrium. When spring C is pulled horizontally by distance ab = 0.6 m, it extends by some amount s.

The force provided by spring C must balance the horizontal component of the tension in the rope. Since the pulley changes the direction of the force: k₂s = T_rope = k₁x₀ = mg = (2 kg)(9.8 m/s²) = 19.6 N
When object A rises by height h, the rope length changes. Since the pulley is fixed, and the rope passes over it, we need to consider conservation of rope length.
conclusion: The total rope length remains constant, ensuring that spring C extends by exactly h when the endpoint moves from a to b.
h = 0.6 m (the object rises by the same amount as the horizontal pull)
